As they grew up, they wanted to go on a trading expedition to the ocean to seek treasures. Each had five hundred attendants, and they set out in front and behind.
The journey was long and they ran out of provisions, enduring seven days of hunger, close to death.

At that time, Subhadra and the merchants all sincerely prayed to the spirits, wishing to be saved from hunger and hardship. In the wilderness, they saw a tree with luxuriant branches and leaves, and immediately went towards it.
There was a spring. Subhadra and the group all sincerely sought protection and rescue.
Moved by their sincerity, a spirit appeared and said to them:
'Chop off a branch, and what you need will come out.'
The people rejoiced and chopped off a branch, and delicious drinks flowed out.
They chopped a second branch, and various kinds of food came out, with a hundred flavors complete. They all received it and each was satisfied.
They chopped a third branch, and wonderful clothes came out, with all kinds complete.
He cut the fourth branch, and various treasures were all complete, fully adorned, and all the necessities were provided.
When Evil-Seeking arrived later, the people were as before, all satisfied, and he thought to himself:
Now this branch of the tree can produce such various good things, let alone its roots!
I should cut it down now, and I will be able to obtain extremely wonderful and excellent things.
His mind was set on this thought, and he had people cut it down.
At that time, Good-Seeking, hearing such words, was filled with resentment and distress, and said to Evil-Seeking:
We were hungry and our lives were at stake. We have been saved by the kindness of this tree and have been able to sustain our remaining lives.
How can you harbor such a vile and evil mind and want to cut it down?
At that time, Evil-Seeking did not heed his words and immediately dug up its roots.
Good-Seeking was moved and could not bear to see it, so he led his people back home.
